threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: the secondary core on the CC3220SF is in charge of the wireless stack and the security mechanisms

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: as such, _you are not allowed to change the code running on the secondary core_

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: this is done like that _by design_

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: _other_ MCUs with multiple cores are, _by design_, done in a way where you control the code on _both_ cores

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: you _still_ need some form of IPC between the cores

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: you can try to reverse engineer them, but that is non-trivial to do

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: so the basic answer is: no

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: if you need access to the communications stack to change things, then that means you did not spec your parts properly

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: you have an API which you can use to talk to the Zigbee stack

threads.author: haadinho10.
threads.content:
1) Take any STM32 board (Blue pill/Blackpill/nucleo). Set up a 100Hz timer (up counter) and see it on oscilloscope by outputing the value to DAC (If you have a scope)
2) When an overflow happens, read in data from any analog GPIO and transfer it by DMA to RAM
3) When the DMA transfer is complete, trigger an interrupt that will send the saved value via any available UART (You can choose the baud rate)
4) See the value transmitted by uart by displaying it in a serial terminal (You can connect from your laptop to serial port using an FTDI cable)

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content: It really depends on which one, if you use "weak" ones Https might be too intense. HTTP is a very bad idea as the insecurity makes your entire chip be at risk.

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content: it is

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content: How do you want to connect it to the internet ?

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content: Do you know how something like that usually works ?

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content: (have you done something like this before?)

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content: no, over-the-air updating, or updating the firmware of a chip from that chip

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content:
I honestly have no idea how your ethernet chip works, but essentially you will at some point write the the flash memory of your chip, the chip you are currently running from.
This is not really trivial as the code you are using to update and write to the flash is, itself, on the flash

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content:
System i know solve this by partitioning their code into 2 section, a factory firmware and OTA firmware, if an update occures the factory writes to the OTA partition and boots THAT program.
Should an error occure during OTA then it is "rolled back" and the factory is booted.

I am not sure but i doubt its feasible to do this on a chip that has itself only 256 kb flash and no in-built partitioning system ...

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content: In practice you are cutting your flash into 2 distinct firmwares. and if you mess up the adresses, chances are you brick the chip into some unrecoverable state, especially if the bootloader or similar critical software is also on that flash

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content:
You could, theoretically, write 2 distinct functions into two seperate regions of flash memory, and depending on which firmware you want to boot you jump to that address blindly.
And the first function handles "updating" the flash code of the other one

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content: no idea if the chip supports writing to flash tho

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content:
They do it more or less the same way, they have a locked partition for the factory "operating system" that is currently running. you run your user code and all other fun stuff in a seperate partition that is read/write.
On a firmware update, the reboot mounts the read only as RW and writes the new operating system to it. then it reboots again mounts it as read only again and then boots into it.

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content: "factory reset" on phone just formats the partitions of the rw user data, effectively throwing them out the door

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content: and presto, you have an "empty" phone

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content:
And usually its actually split into even more parts
A -> Base operating System
B -> Base with firmware updates
C -> User data

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content: so that if your firmware updated bricks the phone, only B and C are dead, not the core

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content: and then one level lower is the bootloader, which is by all means "untouchable" unless outside software tells it to unlock

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content: best bet is HTTP POST binary blob datatype

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content: base64 encoded binary data is your best bet i think, you need to "unwrap" it on the microcontroller but anything else is hell to transfer

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content:
Let me just stress, if you are doing this @Deleted User  you are running a very real risk of bricking your chip if you write to the flash partitions, it depends a lot on the chips MMU behavior.
There be dragons, this can fail spectacularly if done incorrectly; bricking your chip.

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content:
Also: there are a LOT of small and very annoying details when sending raw data. make sure whatever you are sending it from actually pours out data in a way that you expect it to.
I've had many fun instances where the sender thought it fun to put a rouge " in front of the datastream, effectively bricking it

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content: in other words: add a magic byte to the start of your firmware to absolutely confirm it valid before doing anything with it

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content: Its a word of warning, i just hope to raise caution

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content: Ofc, if you do it correctly everything works out \m/

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content:
buuut if your program runs on a page that is currently in RAM, you write to the flash on an address you THINK is clear to write on but your chip then tries to load the page, it might load assembly that it from a completly different firmware. 
no way that ends well

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content: I bricked a few chips that way, i am just warning ya to check every step of the way before doing anything

threads.author: zweieuro
threads.content: making sure your entire program is in RAM before you write to the flash

yep. 
But remote bricks are practically lethal as well. Imagine your ... smart coffee machine makes a firmware update, doesn't do this correctly or the power fails while only running 1 partition aaaand BAM the thing is effectively dead

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content:
for programming, you need:
- GND, VCC for power, obviously
- RST, to enter reset mode
- MOSI, MISO, SCK for the data

so 6 pins.

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: yes, always

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: for programming, you can just connect it to VDD

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: well no, they are not "in series". the issue goes deeper

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: about to tell you

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: for VDD vs AVDD: you usually dont want to use the same supply here. the VDD net is polluted with digital switching noise. that would make your analog measurements worse. if you care for ADC precision, then you want a separate low noise source for AVDD. usually that is done with an LC filter or a ferrite beat, to keep it clean

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: and for the multiple VDD pins: if they were to connect them internally, you would not have the chance to decouple them properly. by routing out these pins one by one, you can add a capacitor to each one

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: bigger chips or more complicated ones (like stm32h7) have a bunch of VDD and GND pins, each one needs their own decoupling cap. ultimatevely they are on the same power net, but you cant get the same low noise with just 1 pin (due to inductance)

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: i answered that in the second section :gotbreWave:

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: no, that can actually damage the chip

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: its not uncommon to have 4 to 8 VDD pairs on a chip

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: but that way, you can reduce the inductance a lot and give each pin its own stable supply

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: and as chip speeds go higher, that is needed

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: at 20MHz you dont need much, but at 800MHz....

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: i would *always* use at least 1 100nF cap per VCC/GND pair. for slower chips like the AVRs that is okay. others may even need 2. and then *at least* one 1uF to 10ÂµF bulk cap for the entire 3.3V/5V grid

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: all depends on the task. sometimes 20MHz is enough, sometimes 200MHz are needed

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content:
not much. touchgfx is just another library, not different from the rest. the hard part is getting it to link properly, rest is easy.

freertos: the hard part here is finding a reason for it :kek: 
cause so far, i never needed it. people always think they need it, they dont. they just need to properly write their program to use interrupts, then they would be fine.

RTOS for me starts once i have a powerful application processor and i need to run something like a car entertainment system. anything below that can easily be done without an rtos of any kind.

most tasks people use MCUs for are just 1-2 realtime tasks at most, and a few background tasks (display, buttons, wifi....). so no need for rtos.

regarding freerots itself: the api isnt bad. you can use most of the typical C-multithreading on there as well. api feels similar in my opinion

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content:
**Absolutely** :gotbreTeach: 

in fact, i am a hardcore C++ fan. however, since i started with python, my productivity skyrocketed. there is no point to use C++ for everything, and i say that as someone who loves that language to death. but the right tool for the right job. and most tasks of a developer are actually *not* just coding up the main firmware, but also testing it (e.g. with a python scripted testing system), logging data (via uart which a python script reads into a file and plots your sensor data), or controlling some peripheral on the computer (also quickly done via python). or in our company right now, i am using a python based flashing system which automates the flashing of our SBCs. 

could i do all of that in C++? yes. but it would take way longer to write. python has a faster development cycle. for the actual firmware i still use C++ of course.

but yes, learning it will *absolutely* benefit you, especially if you do more than just code-monkey stuff, but actual full development

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content:
10ÂµF is on the lower side. i usually have a small little programming board for the THT parts, and that board has a 100ÂµF cap.
and for SMD parts, i program them in-place. and the final pcb already has these caps in place

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content:
freertos is like a trebuchet.
is it powerful? yeah
is it cool? yeah
do you need it for everyday tasks? basicly never.
can you use it to get to the store? sure. but you can also just drive there.

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content:
i personally go with 10-100ÂµF for the rail, and then 100nF per VDD. for analog pins, i usualy go with a lossy 1ÂµH inductor + 100nF + 1ÂµF.

is that overkill? maybe. but it also does not cost much, just cents.
i have not run extensive tests with different noise sweeps, so i cant tell you if that is **the best** solution. a better one might be out there.

threads.content: in that case, you need a good analog decoupling. but keep in mind that most stm32 just have ~20 analog channels

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content:
well for breadboarding, the THT chips usually have 1 to 2 pairs anyway. so just adding 1 more cap wont hurt you.

can you get away with it? usually yes. but why add this extra error source?.

and for programming, i program mostly in-circuit, so i lay out the PCB first, solder on the IC, and then program it. so the MCU is already in a well decoupled configuration

```makefile
build: firmware.bin

firmware.elf: $(SOURCES)
    arm-none-eabi-gcc $(SOURCES) $(CFLAGS) $(LDFLAGS) -o $@

firmware.bin: firmware.elf
    arm-none-eabi-objcopy -O binary $< $@

flash: firmware.bin
    st-flash --reset write $< 0x8000000

clean:
    $(RM) firmware.*
```

threads.author: zecritic
threads.content: IIRC only the STLink/v3 is picky about what chips you connect to. I suppose some locked down dev board JLink OB firmware might care too, but most of the rest are happy to serve as a dumb channel to bit ang SWD or JTAG to anything you want

threads.author: zecritic
threads.content: There are lots of generic CMSIS DAP probes and STLink/V2 clones out there in a variety of form factors

threads.author: zecritic
threads.content: Everyone has their preferences. I tend to use openocd, but I've also used Segger JFlash, and others here may suggest the open source STLink software for STLink, and there's also BlackMagic Debug app and probe-rs that are mostly hardware agnostic.

threads.author: zecritic
threads.content: For production programming Segger is pretty common because they provide commercial support. For hobby stuff you can use whatever, but on the production line they may not want to futz around with your software or your random AliExpress debug probe

threads.author: zecritic
threads.content: They also generally have pretty broad support for chips and good performance where flashing time equals money, but that advantage has been worn down a bit over time

threads.content: yes! i have in fact a few recommendations :gotbreWave:

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content:
stm32f103. simple chip, my replacement for AVR chips. it can do most tasks you wish for a modern controller. but it also shines in no aspect. a good alrounder if your project does not have much requirements.

stm32g431. very good signal processing chip. if you do DSP, that chip is your friend, analog stuff, power conversion stuff, that kind of thing.

stm32f411: a more powerful version of the f103. its a good drop-in upgrade. faster, more memory, higher usb speed. if your project requires something which the f103 cant handle, give this one a try

stm32h755. application processor. that one packs quite some speed, its even faster than some older x86 machines. the last step before you jump into SBC / SoC land

threads.author: gotbread

Here is how you can set that access:
```
#Get udev rules from the STMCube
cd <your STM32CubeProgrammer install directory>/Drivers/rules
sudo cp *.* /etc/udev/rules.d/

#reload udev rules
sudo udevadm control --reload-rules
```

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content:
Arch is a rolling release. It does not support partial upgrades without stuff breaking.
However, the way I use my machine is that every now and then I want to install a single package, but otherwise keep the rest stable. Especially the glibc. I don't always want to update the whole system just because python went from 3.12 to 3.13.
While I loved everything else about arch, especially gnome needed special treatment. Every second new version had a broken icon dependency where I had to hunt down some package to get the proper icons to appear in the menus again.
At some point, I was managing a custom ffmpeg version needed for a self compiled obs version (since upstream did not have the browser source as input) and that clashed with the system ffmpeg.
So at that point I got fed up. I wanted a stable version, so I went with Ubuntu Lts.
Not a fan of the snap store, the older ones (Ubuntu 20) were less annoying in that regard, but hey, I can't have it all.
Give me a rollingreleaseless arch or a snapless Ubuntu and I am happy.

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content:
for example, this is a simple assembly program to run the UART on an AVR:
```
.include "m8def.inc"

.def temp    = r16                              ; Register fÃ¼r kleinere Arbeiten
.def zeichen = r17                              ; In diesem Register wird das Zeichen an die
                                                ; Ausgabefunktion Ã¼bergeben.

.equ F_CPU = 4000000                            ; Systemtakt in Hz
.equ BAUD  = 9600                               ; Baudrate

; Berechnungen
.equ UBRR_VAL   = ((F_CPU+BAUD*8)/(BAUD*16)-1)  ; clever runden
.equ BAUD_REAL  = (F_CPU/(16*(UBRR_VAL+1)))      ; Reale Baudrate
.equ BAUD_ERROR = ((BAUD_REAL*1000)/BAUD-1000)  ; Fehler in Promille

.if ((BAUD_ERROR>10) || (BAUD_ERROR<-10))       ; max. +/-10 Promille Fehler
  .error "Systematischer Fehler der Baudrate grÃ¶sser 1 Prozent und damit zu hoch!"
.endif

    ; Stackpointer initialisieren

    ldi     temp, HIGH(RAMEND)
    out     SPH, temp
    ldi     temp, LOW(RAMEND)
    out     SPL, temp

    ; Baudrate einstellen

    ldi     temp, HIGH(UBRR_VAL)
    out     UBRRH, temp
    ldi     temp, LOW(UBRR_VAL)
    out     UBRRL, temp

    ; Frame-Format: 8 Bit

    ldi     temp, (1<<URSEL)|(1<<UCSZ1)|(1<<UCSZ0)
    out     UCSRC, temp

    sbi     UCSRB, TXEN

loop:
    ldi     zeichen, 'T'
    rcall   serout 
    ldi     zeichen, 'e'
    rcall   serout 
    ldi     zeichen, 's'
    rcall   serout 
    ldi     zeichen, 't'
    rcall   serout
    ldi     zeichen, '!'
    rcall   serout
    ldi     zeichen, 10
    rcall   serout
    ldi     zeichen, 13
    rcall   serout
    rcall   sync                        
    rjmp    loop

serout:
    sbis    UCSRA, UDRE

    rjmp    serout
    out     UDR, zeichen
    ret

sync:
    ldi     r16, 0
sync_1:
    ldi     r17, 0
sync_loop:
    dec     r17
    brne    sync_loop
    dec     r16
    brne    sync_1
    ret
```

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content:
Yeah, that is normal. The HAL is basicly not debugable.
Your best bet at troubleshooting is to read the section in the reference manual. For dual mode, the dma bit needs to be enabled, regardless of dma use. Then you can either manually start it and sample, or have it sampled by the dma.

To troubleshoot, ditch that Hal call, set up the registers. First single channel mode, get that to work. Once that works, you can go to simultaneous sampling with the dma bit. Your output word then contains 2 channels in 1 32 bit sample.

threads.author: beer_baron
threads.content: I use this for release `-O3 -ggdb0 -flto`

threads.author: beer_baron
threads.content:
```
-Og

Optimize debugging experience. -Og should be the optimization level of choice for the standard edit-compile-debug cycle, offering a reasonable level of optimization while maintaining fast compilation and a good debugging experience. It is a better choice than -O0 for producing debuggable code because some compiler passes that collect debug information are disabled at -O0.

Like -O0, -Og completely disables a number of optimization passes so that individual options controlling them have no effect. Otherwise -Og enables all -O1 optimization flags except for those that may interfere with debugging.
```

threads.author: beer_baron
threads.content:
With this one I was able to reduce binaries of 50MB `-Oz` down to 3MB or 2MB: ```-Oz
Optimize aggressively for size rather than speed. This may increase the number of instructions executed if those instructions require fewer bytes to encode. -Oz behaves similarly to -Os including enabling most -O2 optimizations.```

threads.author: beer_baron
threads.content:
For me it would be more valuable as a beginner to have a device I could play with, such as a raspberry, beaglebone or any of those... I think it is better to have a device you can control on the other side when learning...

I think with one of these devices you would be able to build and see the full picture of the secure boot chain, including the proprietary bootloaders of the mediatek / qualcomm / broadcom / whatever chip, software like uboot / little kernel, trusted execution environment if one is needed, maybe hardware security chips like TPMs, trust zone of the chip, device trees and how they are signed (FIT), dm-verity and avb formats...

I am not sure how I would tackle this as a beginner just with a device that is a secured black box that I would need to reverse engineer, to begin with most information about the black box device itself is probably behind paywall or innacessible

Thanks in Advance.

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: correct. you can use the cores MPU unit to mark sections, one of the attributes is the cachability

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: https://developer.arm.com/documentation/dui0646/c/Cortex-M7-Peripherals/Optional-Memory-Protection-Unit/MPU-access-permission-attributes?lang=en#BIHHEDAE here you can see the cache policies

threads.author: onwrikbaar
threads.content: Alternatively, call SCB_InvalidateDCache_by_Addr() in the DMA interrupt handler before processing the transferred data to ensure that it is not stale.

threads.content:
Putting a checklist on this issue:
1. GPIOC clock is on
2. PC4 is set as an input
3. PC4 has its pullup enabled
4. EXTI Falling Trigger 4 is enabled
5. EXTI falling trigger 4 is unmasked
6. NVIC priority for EXTI4-15 is set at 1
7. NVIC enable for EXTI4-15 has been called.
8. EXTI4_15_IRQHandler is defined

Yet pulling PC4 to ground does not fire the ISR

threads.author: cooperg2001

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: a single USB port actually provides two devices: a USB-CDC device (UART to USB bridge), as well as a CMSIS-DAP debugger

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: both are implemented using the single USB controller on the RP2040

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: the thing is that when you connect something to a USB port on your machine it goes into a shared bus

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content:
on the machine in front of me:
```
Bus 001 Device 005: ID 32ac:0014 Framework Laptop 16 Numpad Module
Bus 001 Device 006: ID 0e8d:e616 MediaTek Inc. Wireless_Device
Bus 001 Device 007: ID 27c6:609c Shenzhen Goodix Technology Co.,Ltd. Goodix Fingerprint USB Device
Bus 001 Device 008: ID 32ac:0012 Framework Laptop 16 Keyboard Module - ANSI
```

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: these devices are all on the same bus

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: that's my number pad, bluetooth adapter, fingerprint reader, and keyboard

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: it's all grouped under the same bus

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: the keyboard driver talks to the USB subsystem in the kernel

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: the USB subsystem arbitrates bus accesses

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: at the end of the day though, as you say, each device has its own D+ and D- line

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: but both the hub they are connected to in the machine in collaboration with the software handle contention issues

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: if i connect the raspberry pi debug probe to my laptop, it comes out under a single bus, single device

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: the kernel sees _two_ devices though: the USB-CDC and the CMSIS-DAP

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: so now, when i do USB-CDC related stuff (accessing the serial port from, say, `/dev/ttyACM0`) the CDC subsystem in the kernel talks to the USB subsystem and places a request on that particular bus+device

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: at the same time, on a different core, i could be doing something with the CMSIS-DAP part

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: (this is done using the `/dev/bus/usb` interface on my machine, so I am talking directly to the USB subsystem)

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: the USB subsystem places a request on that particular bus+device

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: now, the endpoints are different (iirc)

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: [this is the part i am not 100% sure on]

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: the kernel can't have two things try to send out data out of the same device at the same time

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: it would place the USB controller on my machine in a very poor state

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: so things need to be scheduled to come out

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: the RP2040 on the debug probe receives the data, processes the endpoint, and does what it needs to do with it

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: but yeah, the kernel on my machine is smart enough not to try to do two transactions over the same port at the same time

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: [the kernel is actually really dumb, but the people who wrote it made it behave in a sane way]

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: sadly, this is one of those times where the friendly manual is severely lacking

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: the RP2040 is, in my opinion, one of the worst documented parts i have dealt with

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: this is especially evident if you decide to throw away the SDK and do things on your own

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: i would have rather they not have you use UF2

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: that format is a bit clunky

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: we had the intel HEX format for years

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: it did the same thing, and it had been an industry standard for quite some time

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: have never tried it with ELF

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: [not like I use UF2 either most of the time]

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: i normally have a CMSIS-DAP probe connected to my RP2040 and load the code into it using OpenOCD

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: so no need to disconnect and reconnect it whilst asserting the boot pin

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: SWD

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: if you have a Pi Pico board, the SWD port is the three pin header (or connector) opposite to the USB port

also, if you have a Pi Pico board you can turn it into a CMSIS-DAP probe (as well as a USB-UART bridge) if you install the debugprobe firmware on it:

threads.author: cooperg2001
threads.content:
Okay using their words:
if Bootloader detects App Loader corruption then you lose DFU unless the App Loader corruption was caused by a botched App Loader update in which case you run the active App slot which will still contain the Updater which will then repair the App Loader (assuming the update itself is not the cause of fault)

threads.author: cooperg2001
threads.content: This is where things like checking your ECC if you have it and pro-actively repairing detected errors would save you since this kind of corruption would typically be caused by hardware wearout or cosmic rays

threads.author: cooperg2001
threads.content: You can def fit it on 1 sector

threads.author: cooperg2001
threads.content:
well depending on the sector and how much smarts you want.

Mine can just do CRC and flash an LED.

Fits easily in the 2K sector size on an STM32G0

threads.author: cooperg2001
threads.content: I used the same pattern on a TM4C1294NCPDT with 16K sectors ofc it also fits with sooo much wasted space due to the huge sector size

threads.author: cooperg2001
threads.content: The App Loader also fits within a 16K sector and that was with USB drivers for DFU and mass storage

threads.author: cooperg2001
threads.content: That won't fix your problem cause now you have to worry about if that gets corrupted instead

threads.author: cooperg2001
threads.content:
Needing to load a seperate 2nd Stage updater into an app slot is fine.

If you want to protect against corruption then read up on your chips CRC, ECC, Write Protection, etc systems and implement an error checking and correction routine

threads.author: cooperg2001
threads.content: Eventually it will fail in a way you can't prevent but if you do all that it will be robust enough

threads.author: cooperg2001
threads.content: Now that said if you have the space you could do both and have updates fail to the backup factory burned updater image. Thats a design decision you'll have to make

threads.author: cooperg2001
threads.content: However note that your factory update image will limit how you can change your future update mechanisms since it would be a static thing

threads.author: cooperg2001
threads.content: Your updater typically should not just be a flat "write input code to this address" you still want to verify the incoming firmware update is valid for your system

threads.author: cooperg2001
threads.content:
Otherwise imagine if your 2nd stage is corrupt you fail back to the updater to replace it and then a user happens to plug in some rando .bin file.

Now your device is happily scribbling who knows what into flash

threads.author: cooperg2001
threads.content:
The most basic way to prevent this is to include some magic number and a CRC with your firmware image.

The secure way is to do that but also encrypt it.

The first means at least someone bothered to give you a value to check

The second means only you or authorized parties can make firmware bundles that your device will load

threads.author: cooperg2001
threads.content: but the user has the device and presumably has some mechanism on their end to trigger the update

threads.author: cooperg2001
threads.content:
if the only way for the device to get firmware updates is via some encrypted internet channel to  a server you control then this issue is mitigated. 

If you give out an update file they load the  you need more verification less they load some random garbage

threads.author: cooperg2001
threads.content: Because if you don't verify whats going in there then it becomes much easier to brick your device or break DFU

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: i was working with a device that had a very sparse ISA

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: so most instruction words would readily decode to an invalid instruction

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: ISA as in instruction set architecture, not the ISA bus on old PCs

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: the entire idea was based on instruction set randomization

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: instructions were fetched encrypted and decrypted in the CPU's pipeline

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: if you tamper with the instruction stream somehow, because of the sparsity of the ISA you are very likely to end with an invalid instruction being decrypted and the CPU would then go into a secure illegal instruction trap

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: modified RISC-V core

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: i modified a RISC-V core to do that stuff

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: [btw, if you apply this same techique in x86, you only need to execute about 3 instructions before you crash]

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: so this method of "hiding" software even works if your ISA is dense

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: the NXP LPC55S69 does something similar, btw

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: that thing has a cryptographic core that sits in between the CPU's instruction port and flash memory

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: if you activate it, instructions are fetched from flash and decrypted on the fly

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: if i may brag a little bit: i've met one of the people who designed that system

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: Cortex-M cores have an optional memory protection unit (MPU)

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: they do not have a full blown MMU

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: you can divide memory into regions using the MPU

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: however, the permissions for regions are checked using the CPU's state

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: [privileged vs unprivileged]

threads.author: hard.fault
threads.content: Not the M4. But TrustZone on the M33 for example is designed for this exact use case

threads.author: hard.fault
threads.content: You could, as Tron suggests, configure the mpu as you switch tasks or enter/exit interrupts. But TrustZone automates this by way of having trusted system calls and two complete processor contexts where it'll switch between the two depending on the code that's executing

threads.author: beer_baron
threads.content: I recently had a problem of losing like just a few bytes in RTS / CTS UART at high baudrates with stress testing, as in 3 bytes or so in 10MB loopback and not every test iteration... after some headache with queues and race conditions I ended figuring it was the CH340 based usb2ttl in between, and a (real) FTDI2226 fixed it :/

threads.author: beer_baron
threads.content: that was draining but good to know

threads.author: beer_baron
threads.content: note that if using std::function for callbacks with lambda it might use the heap due to the captures, looking into fixed_function or function_ref kind of stuff is worth but I don't think there is anything standard yet

threads.author: beer_baron
threads.content: for the callback itself? I think if you have state to handle either you capture via lambda (which can use the heap) or you pass the state as in a context argument, if using the lambda you need function or you use like a function pointer and ensure it exists for long enough (e.g. not in the stack of the caller function)

threads.author: beer_baron
threads.content: The embedded template library has this (I haven't used it): https://www.etlcpp.com/delegate.html

threads.author: hard.fault
threads.content: You could, as Tron suggests, configure the mpu as you switch tasks or enter/exit interrupts. But TrustZone automates this by way of having trusted system calls and two complete processor contexts where it'll switch between the two depending on the code that's executing

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: it should be mentioned that the security extension requires you to configure the SAU (and in some systems the IDAU); the former works more or less the same way as the MPU; you will need to have a veneer area, and you still need to rely switching the CPU from a secure mode to a non-secure mode

threads.author: hard.fault
threads.content: Right; but in terms of peripheral access, once it's set up you don't have to rewrite the security settings on every switch

threads.content: so, for example, if you needed to remap the MPU every time you do an RTOS context switch...

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: different hardware peripherals

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: different memory layout

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: the f103 has a Cortex-M3 core

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: the f401 has a Cortex-M4 core

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: so all in all, very different devices

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: so both the M4 and M3 implement the ARMv7-M ISA

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: the M4 usually has DSP extensions

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: so for startup, you should be able to use the same runtime

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: as long as you populate your vector table using some symbols from the linker (for end of RAM for example)

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: you should be fine

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: long story short, code that needs to set up the environment the way C expects it to be before you get into `main()`

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: and code that handles the behavior C dictates after `main()` returns

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: for bare metal code, that means setting up the `.data` and `.bss` sections, handling global constructors, and the likes

threads.author: madman.in.a.box
threads.content: and then after `main()` exits, handling whatever got registered with `atexit()` running the global destructors, and the likes

threads.author: rustedskull
threads.content:
Again. JTAG/SWD and vcom are two separate topics. Implementing JTAG or SWD will not get you vcom.

Stlinks on nucleo boards have additional capability of translating a UART line into a vcom.

Standalone STlink V2 lacks this capability.
It looks like a standalone STLink V3 does have this capability.
And it could be that you can wire a UART into your nucleo board's STLink header for it to do the same.

But for this to be possible, in addition to the SWD lines, you must expose a UART line pair on your board.

threads.author: rustedskull
threads.content: Alternatively you can add a UART to USB bridge chip onto your board, along with a USB plug, and get a vcom directly from your board, without needing STLink at all.

threads.author: beyerrrrrr
threads.content: the garbage byte is sent as soon as you initialize uart?

threads.author: beyerrrrrr
threads.content:
```
1. Enable the USART by writing the UE bit in USART_CR1 register to 1.
2. Program the M bit in USART_CR1 to define the word length.
3. Program the number of stop bits in USART_CR2.
4. Select DMA enable (DMAT) in USART_CR3 if Multi buffer Communication is to take
place. Configure the DMA register as explained in multibuffer communication.
5. Select the desired baud rate using the USART_BRR register.
6. Set the TE bit in USART_CR1 to send an idle frame as first transmission.
7. Write the data to send in the USART_DR register (this clears the TXE bit). Repeat this
for each data to be transmitted in case of single buffer.
8. After writing the last data into the USART_DR register, wait until TC=1. This indicates
that the transmission of the last frame is complete. This is required for instance when
the USART is disabled or enters the Halt mode to avoid corrupting the last
transmission.
``` these are the uart steps from the rm (of the f4)

threads.author: beer_baron
threads.content:
This would be unilateral tls, that bundle of certs will try to verify the certificate shown by the server, if adding cert_pem, it would be bilateral tls, in which the server will also verify the client

In the case of unilateral tls you might have some setting to skip verification and force the client to trust the server (--insecure in curl, for example), and you do not need certificates at all... At least for testing
